occurrences.line_text: He can deuize this counter-cast of slight,
It euer can recured be againe;
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
Who can him cure, that will be cur'd of none?
The best (sayd he) that I can you aduize,
Nor heauens, nor men can me most wretched mayd
Doe them afflict, which no man can appease,
As they doe know each can most aptly vse.
To which what can compare?) can it compare;
To which what can compare?) can it compare;
For being gone, none can them bring in place,
Who can aread, what creature mote she bee,
And flyes away as fast as he can hye,
For other none such passion can contriue
With Canacee and Cambine linckt in louely bond.
Cambelloes sister was fayre Canacee,
In loue of Canacee they ioyned all:
Cambell for Canacee.
For Canacee with Cambell for to fight:
Fayre Canacee vpon a stately stage
And Canacee gan wayle her dearest frend.
All which, when gentle Canacee beheld,
Faire Canacee, as fresh as morning rose,
For Triamond had Canacee to wife,
The face of his deare Canacee vnheale;
But Triamond lou'd Canacee, and other none.
And placed vnder stately canapee,
That cunning Architect of cancred guile,
Therein a cancred crabbed Carle does dwell,
From inward parts, with cancred malice lind,
Certes Clarinda, not of cancred will,
Agreeing in bad will and cancred kynd,
In cancred malice and reuengefull spright.
But now weake age had dimd his candle light.
But with continuall candlelight, which delt
And eke but hardly seene by candle-light:
And makes huge hauocke, whiles the candlelight
And lighting candles new, gan search anone,
That were all worme-eaten, and full of canker holes.
O cursed Eld the cankerworme of writs,
Betweene his cankred teeth a venemous tode,
With these his wicked sons, and shewd his cankred hate.
They cannot finde that path, which first was showne,
In vaine he seekes that hauing cannot hold.
Thy sad tongue cannot tell more heauy plight,
And what I cannot quite, requite with vsuree.
Cannot describe, nor wit of man can tell;
Hart cannot thinke, what outrage, and what cryes,
My narrow leaues cannot in them containe
But since that band ye cannot now release,
Behaues with cares, cannot so easie mis.
Cannot your glorious pourtraict figure plaine
For liuing wit, I weene, cannot display
Can doe (said she) that, which cannot be donne.
And yield your heart, whence ye cannot remoue?
Or whence it sprong, I cannot read aright:
Cannot with noble Britomart compare,
Cannot endure, but needs it must be wrackt
Sith I her dew reward cannot restore:
In vaine he feares that, which he cannot shonne:
Cannot two fairer Cities find this day,
Cannot employ your most victorious speare
What boots it plaine, that cannot be redrest,
Ne worldly price cannot redeeme my deare,
What boots it then to plaine, that cannot be redrest?
Such ones ill iudge of loue, that cannot loue,
The which these Stoicke censours cannot well deny.
Cannot find one this girdle to inuest.
For which Dan Phebus selfe cannot a salue prouide.
Whom without perill he cannot inuade.
That liues a loathed life, and wishing cannot die.
Which sith they cannot in this Canto well
Cannot recount, nor tell their hidden race,
Ill can he rule the great, that cannot reach the small.
Or with her owne good will, I cannot read aright.
Though they enforce themselues, cannot attaine.
Cannot redressed be by liuing wight.
Find remedie vnsought, which seeking cannot fynd.
Sith he cannot expresse his simple minde,
That all her peres cannot with her compare,
His stubborne steed with curbed canon bit,
Why fearest thou, that canst not hope for thing,
Thou canst preserue from wrong and robbery?
Ne canst of prowesse, ne of knighthood deeme,
False loue, why do men say, thou canst not see,
Ne canst her ayde, ne canst her foe dismay:
Ne canst her ayde, ne canst her foe dismay:
Of things vnseene how canst thou deeme aright,
Whose counsels depth thou canst not vnderstand,
But if the weight of these thou canst not show,
For how canst thou those greater secrets know,
To which if thou canst win him any way,
With which thou canst euen Ioue himselfe to loue entise.
With which in case thou canst him not inuade,
Whom by no meanes thou canst recall againe;
Shall for another canticle be spared.
Now Cantium, which Kent we commenly inquire.
But rather will reserue it for a Canto new.
Which sith they cannot in this Canto well
So ended he his tale, where I this Canto end.
Vnto an other Canto I will ouerpas.
Which in an other Canto will be best contayned.
That for another Canto will more fitly fall.
Where what ensu'd, shall in next Canto be begonne.
That in another Canto shall to end be brought.
Will in an other Canto better be begonne.
Were like mayne-yards, with flying canuas lynd,
Or winged canuas with the wind to flie,
All in a canuas thin he was bedight,
But Canute had his portion from the rest,
The which he cald Canutium, for his hyre;
At bold Canutus; but of him was slaine anon.
And on his head a steele cap he did weare
By their faire handling, put into Malbeccoes cape.
In great displeasure, wild a Capias
And euermore their cruell Capitaine
And euermore their wicked Capitaine
That he, which was their Capitaine profest,
Two brethren were their Capitains, which hight
That Capons courage: yet he looked grim,
And Eglantine, and Caprifole emong,
Them in twelue troupes their Captain did dispart
Nor leaue his stand, vntill his Captaine bed.
When as their Captaine heard, in haste he yode,
Were brought vnto their Captaine, who was set
This their request the Captaine much appalled;
To whom the Captaine in full angry wize
But then the Captaine fraught with more displeasure,
Was by the Captaine all this while defended:
Their Captaine there they cruelly found kild,
Their Captaine long withstood, & did her death forstall.
By reason that the Captaines on her side,
Braue Captaines, and most mighty warriours,
Of mighty Conquerours and Captaines strong,
With which he streight went to the Captaines nest.
But the two knights themselues their captains did subdew.
The whole discourse of his captiuance sad,
Whom he had reskewed from captiuaunce
Captiu'd to fortune and frayle worldly feares,
Wherein captiu'd, of life or death he stood in doubt.
Thus when as Guyon Furor had captiu'd,
Captiu'd eternally in yron mewes,
Frayle men are oft captiu'd to couetise:
Rather then fly, or be captiu'd her selfe she slew.
But the captiu'd Acrasia he sent,
She lenger yet is like captiu'd to bee:
In which captiu'd she many moneths did mourne,
And saw him selfe captiu'd, he was dismayd,
To be captiu'd, and handled as he list,
Her captiue to his sensuall desire,
The Redcrosse knight is captiue made
That he my captiue langour should redeeme,
For till I haue acquit your captiue knight,
And that weake captiue wight now wexed strong,
To thinke of those her captiue Parents deare,
Dye, or thy selfe my captiue yield for ay;
And to her captiue sonne yield his first libertee.
In captiue bandes, which there they readie found:
And some for wrath, to see their captiue Dame:
Late King, now captiue, late Lord, now forlorne,
He left his captiue Beast at liberty,
And captiue with her led to wretchednesse and wo.
They haue him taken captiue, though it grieue him sore.
And setst thy kingdome in the captiue harts
Yet she him still detaines in captiue hold
Her captiue louers friend, young Placidas:
Before the ryder, as he captiue were,
He her vnwares attacht, and captiue held by might.
Which was the captiue Squire she lou'd so deare,
And for more ioy, that captiue Lady faire
And now they doe with captiue bands him bind;
Gan cast a secret liking to this captiue straunge.
Yet in the streightnesse of that captiue state,
In which her wretched loue was captiue layd:
For all those Knights, which long in captiue shade
To captiue men, and make them all the world reiect.
He like a dog was led in captiue case,
Then turning backe vnto that captiue thrall,
And all his people captiue led away;
And carried captiue by those theeues away;
Till Fortune would her captiue bonds vnbynde:
Reioyced much to see his captiue plight,
Or enimies powre hath now captiued you,
That long captiued soules from wearie thraldome free.
Which thee to endlesse bale captiued lead.
Faire Ladies, that to loue captiued arre,
To succour wretched wights, whom we captiued see.
To be captiued in endlesse duraunce
Which were whilome captiued in their dayes
Nations captiued, and huge armies slaine:
Where she captiued long, great woes did proue;
Vnto his bay, and captiued her thought.
That him captiued hath in haplesse woe.
An hardie courage, like captiued thrall,
And captiues to redeeme with price of bras,
And therefore prayd, that those same captiues there
But first of all, their captiues they doe kill,
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
Or hold sad life in long captiuitee:
And gan to breake the bands of their captiuitee.
The hidden cause of their captiuitie,
Bring the soule into captiuitie:
And tell the course of his captiuitie;
[I]nto captiuity.
Like captive thral two other Knights atweene,
So led this Knight his captyue with like conquest wonne.
And thee captyued in this shamefull place?
That at his backe a brode Capuccio had,
And had not Carados her hand withheld
Yet Carados himselfe from her escapt with paine.
Then gan Carausius tirannize anew,
Full of diseases was his carcas blew,
For nought he car'd his carcas long vnfed;
Yet liues his memorie, though carcas sleepe in rest.
Sith dint of steele his carcas could not quell:
About some carcase by the common way,
That still for carrion carcases doth craue:
Whose carcases were scattered on the greene,
And their vile carcases now left vnburied.
Whose carcases on ground were horribly prostrate.
With carcases of noble warrioures,
Of carcases, which dying on her fell.
But when they mou'd the carcases aside,
Through the dead carcases he made his way;
Thy carcasse for their pray, the guerdon of thy paine.
And to their sire their carcasses left to bestow.
Ne car'd for bloud in his auengement:
But no man car'd to answere to his crye.
Ne car'd to hoord for those, whom he did breede:
For nought he car'd his carcas long vnfed;
Ne ought he car'd, whom he endamaged
Ne car'd he greatly for her presence vaine,
Remembred he, ne car'd for his saufgard,
Vpon his card and compas firmes his eye,
And wrestle wantonly, ne car'd to hyde,
Withouten compasse, or withouten card,
Beastly he threw her downe, ne car'd to spill
Ne either car'd to ward, or perill shonne,
But naught he car'd for friend or enemy,
But he nought car'd for all that they could say:
To spin, to card, to sew, to wash, to wring;
Thenceforth he car'd no more, which way he strooke,
That went at will, withouten carde or sayle,
Yet neither spinnes nor cardes, ne cares nor frets,
Spinning and carding all in comely rew,
Seemed in heart some hidden care she had,
Watching to banish Care their enimy,
And paynd himselfe with busie care to reare
For of deuotion he had little care,
To leaue them to; but thorough daily care
And hop'd to reape the crop of all my care,
Does care for looke of liuing creatures eye.
Her loue is firme, her care continuall,
The roote of all your care, and wretched plight,
He had enough, what need him care for more?
The first and chiefest of the seuen, whose care
Forgo that royall maides bequeathed care,
His be that care, whom most it doth concerne,
Nor care of vow'd reuenge, and cruell fight,
Ne care, ne feare I, how the wind do blow,
Yet no man for them taketh paines or care,
But to her mother Nature all her care she lets.
That of no wordly thing he care did take;
Ne of his safetie seemed care he kept,
Before the dore sat selfe-consuming Care,
A Nd is there care in heauen? and is there loue
The care thereof my selfe vnto the end,
All naked without shame, or care of cold,
With constancy and care, gainst daunger and dismay.
Not that celestiall powre, to whom the care
For thy great care she tooke, and greater feare,
Her clowdy care into a wrathfull stowre,
And vnto Psyche with great trust and care
Haue care, I pray, to guide the cock-bote well,
He rou'd at her, and told his secret care:
Or care of credite, or of husband old,
That doth with curelesse care consume the hart,
Vnquiet Care, and fond Vnthriftihead,
With busie care they stroue him to awake,
Was Amoret, companion of her care:
His name was Care; a blacksmith by his trade,
Who hauing left that restlesse house of Care,
Her second care, though in another kind;
Ne care he had, ne pittie of the pray,
Him to recomfort in his greatest care,
And eke his deare companion of his care.
And manly limbs endur'd with little care
So was his toyle the more, the more that was his care.
Then either care of parents could refraine,
I neuer ioyed howre, but still with care was moued.
Haue care of right, or ruth of wretches wrong,
And vnderstood the cause of all her care
For loue of Nymphes she thought she need not care,
The care whereof, and hope of his successe
That false Duessa, which had wrought great care,
The Kingdomes care, with a white siluer hed,
Importune care of their owne publicke cause;
Vnto his way, which now was all his care and count.
And leauing Artegall to his owne care;
And from her balefull minde all care he banished.
And watch aduauntage, how to worke his care:
For thing of weight, or worke of greater care,
And for the courteous care, which he did beare
His care more then her owne compassionate,
And twixt them twaine with equall care to cast,
Who with the horrour of her haplesse care
He wore no armour, ne for none did care,
Of finest flowres, and with full busie care
She did conceiue, through care of womanhood,
Did care a whit, ne any liking lend:
And each his sundrie sheepe with seuerall care
Without my care, but onely to attend it;
During his absence left in heauy care,
He was, and cared not for God or man a point.
Ne cared she her course for to apply:
The Conquerour nought cared him to slay,
Ne for them, ne for honour cared hee,
And cared not to spare, that should be shortly spent.
Ne either cared life to saue or spill,
Ne better had he, ne for better cared:
Ne cared as a coward so to be condemned.
He cared not for dint of sword nor speere,
What cared she, who sighed for her sore,
For other worldly wealth they cared nought.
But cared more for Colins carolings
Ne cared she her wound in teares to steepe,
His heauie head, deuoide of carefull carke,
Whose case when as the carefull Dwarfe had tould,
The pitteous maiden carefull comfortlesse,
So fast he carried her with carefull paine,
Sith cruell fates the carefull threeds vnfould,
And euermore in constant carefull mind
The carefull cold beginneth for to creepe,
That when the carefull knight gan well auise,
From that day forth I cast in carefull mind,
And streightway sent with carefull diligence,
To put away out of his carefull brest.
To whom the carefull charge of him she gaue,
As carefull Nourse her child from falling oft does reare.
The gentle knight her soone with carefull paine
Yet no man to them can his carefull paines compare.
The carefull seruant, striuing with his raging Lord.
A carefull man, and full of comely guise:
The noble Elfe, and carefull Palmer drew
She soundly slept, & carefull thoughts did quite assoile.
And taught the carefull Mariner to play,
They graunted it; and then that carefull Fay
Those be vnquiet thoughts, that carefull minds inuade.
There he continued in this carefull plight,
And did so well employ his carefull paine,
That piteously complaind her carefull grieffe,
By that same carefull Squire did then abide,
She chaw'd the cud of louers carefull plight;
Which long he vsd with carefull diligence,
And by them long with carefull labour nurst,
And her sad selfe with carefull hand constrayning
With carefull hands soft footing her beside,
But day and night did vexe her carefull thought,
And weary now with carefull keeping ward,
Howbe that carefull Hermite did his best,
That scarlot whore to keepen carefully;
And the old-woman carefully displayd
And as her Squire attend her carefully:
Who no lesse carefully her tendered,
To counsell her so carefully dismayd,
Yet he his hand so carefully did beare,
Like to a Spaniell wayting carefully
He there did make, and then most carefully
But he did her attend most carefully,
So rich purueyance, ne them keepe with carefulnesse.
And with the tide droue forward careleslie;
There he him found all carelesly displayd,
But suffred her so carelesly disguized
Vncomb'd, vncurl'd, and carelesly vnshed;
And carelesly into the riuer goth,
And with reproch of carelesnesse vnkind
Might there be heard: but carelesse Quiet lyes,
Whiles you in carelesse sleepe are drowned quight.
Her out of carelesse swowne. Her eylids blew
He did disrobe, when all men carelesse slept,
Both carelesse of his health, and of his fame:
But if that carelesse heauens (quoth she) despise
As carelesse of his woe, or innocent
For to allure fraile mind to carelesse ease.
Carelesse the man soone woxe, and his weake wit
Like as the sacred Oxe, that carelesse stands,
And in lewd slouth to wast his carelesse day:
And wilfull want, all carelesse of her needes;
Downe to her foot, with carelesse modestee.
Reproch despightfull, carelesse, and vnkind;
All carelesse of his taunt and bitter rayle,
As she sate carelesse by a cristall flood,
Carelesse of perill in their fiers affret,
That by their many wounds, and carelesse harmes,
Doe spend my dayes, and bend my carelesse wit
In which he liu'd alone, like carelesse bird in cage.
In carelesse couch, not weeting what was ment,
And sitting carelesse on the scorners stoole,
From worldy cares himselfe he did esloyne,
Forgetfull of his owne, that mindes anothers cares.
So doubly is distrest twixt ioy and cares
By triall of his former harmes and cares,
Behaues with cares, cannot so easie mis.
And where he hits, nought knowes, & whom he hurts, nought cares.
Yet neither spinnes nor cardes, ne cares nor frets,
Which with sad cares empeach our natiue ioyes:
To taken counsell of their common cares;
The time, that mortall men their weary cares
Thou art the root and nurse of bitter cares,
Ne cares, what men say of him ill or well;
To drincke hereof, whereby all cares forepast
Scudamour comming to Cares house,
That all the cares and euill which they meet,
And count my cares, when none is nigh to heare,
Cares not what euils hap to wretched wight;
Right sorrowfully mourning her bereaued cares.
But will my cares vnfolde, in hope to find
And store of cares doth follow riches store.
Me no such cares nor combrous thoughts offend,
Wrapped in wretched cares and hearts vnrest,
All which his sonne Careticus awhile
Caried with feruent zeale, ne did he ceasse,
As when two Barkes, this caried with the tide,
Spoyld all our cots, and caried vs from hence?
Not caring how, her silly life to saue,
Not caring his long labours to deface,
Which spake reprochfully, not caring where nor when.
In loathly wise like to a carion corse,
Downe on the ground his carkas groueling fell;
The carkas with the streame was carried downe,
Vpon that milke-white Palfreyes carkas fed,
Like carkases of beasts in butchers stall.
A donghill of dead carkases he spide,
Whose carkases, for terrour of his name,
Another wretch, whose carkasse deepe was drent
Of that same outcast carkasse, that erewhile
And with foule cowardize his carkasse shame,
But for this carkasse pardon I entreat,
And make his carkasse as the outcast dong?
That through his carkasse one might plainely see:
And crusht his carkasse so against his brest,
Of life, she put a Spright to rule the carkasse dead.
And him assayling, sore his carkasse teare,
Vppon the carkasse of some beast too weake,
His carkasse tumbling on the threshold, sent
The carkasse tumbling downe within the dore,
Streight to the carkasse of that Knight he went,
Yet stuck, with carkasses exanimate
Of slaughtred carkasses, her heart did quake
And feedes on all the carkasses, that die
His heauie head, deuoide of carefull carke,
Which when the carle beheld, and saw his guest
And the fiers Carle commaunding to forbeare,
For her defence, against that Carle to fight,
Soone as the Carle from farre the Prince espyde,
Treads downe and ouerthrowes. Now had the Carle
He to the Carle himselfe againe addrest,
No sooner thought, then that the Carle as fast
Who wrongd by Carle by Proteus sau'd,
Therein a cancred crabbed Carle does dwell,
And euermore the Carle of curtesie accusd.
And that vncurteous Carle their commune foe
With that, the wicked carle the maister Smith
Of this accursed Carle of hellish kind;
For hardly could he come the carle to touch,
For of that Carle she sorely bruz'd had beene,
With that selfe arrow, which the Carle had kild:
Of that same wicked Carle, by Virgins hond;
Into the floud: streight leapt the Carle vnblest,
To wreake your wrath on such a carle as hee:
For neither will one foot, till we that carle haue hent.
With noyse whereof when as the caytiue carle
A cruell carle, the which all strangers slew,
They saw that Carle from farre, with hand vnblest
When as the Carle no longer could sustaine,
Looking at that same Carle with count'nance grim,
Led by a Carle and foole, which by her side did passe.
So did the Squire, the whiles the Carle did fret,
Till heauy hand the Carle vpon him layd,
And strooke so strongly, that the Carle with paine
Vppon that Carle, to saue his friend from ieopardy.
Slay not that Carle, though worthy to be slaine:
So end of that Carles dayes, and his owne paines did make.
That for these Carles to carry much more comely were?
With those two Carles, fled fast away, afeard
With stings of carnall lust, and strong effort
Into a cleare Carnation suddeine dyde;
His mistresse prayses, sweetly caroled,
Fit song of Angels caroled to bee;
And told that gardins pleasures in their caroling.
Ay caroling of loue and iollity,
Playing on pypes, and caroling apace,
And caroling her name both day and night,
But cared more for Colins carolings
Whether it were to caroll, as they sate
Hymnes to high God, and carols heauenly things,
Had warned once, that Phoebus fiery carre
His carriage was full comely and vpright,
With sober grace, and goodly carriage:
And laid the blame, not to his carriage,
